properties.Description: REEC bought the leasehold in 2017 for $29M from Edward Gabay, planning a 53,000-sf office building. In 2021, foundations had yet to be dug, and Madison Capital Realty moved to foreclose. Parkview Financial rescued the project with a $70M refi the next year. The 9-story building is still under construction.

REEC bought the leasehold in a 2017 deal valued at $21M. Two years later an entity tied to GDS Development Management and Swedish firm Klovern AB took it over. Plans for an office building were derailed by Covid, and the leasehold went back to Brandon Miller in December 2023. He immediately borrowed $1.5M against the property from Douglas Teitelbaum, who took control of it under the entity DIA Family Holdings after Miller’s death in July. Teitelbaum then put the entity into bankruptcy.

After buying the leasehold in 2020 for $27M, REEC lined up a sale with Elie Schwartz’s Nightingale Properties. The closing deadline was 2025. But Nightingale was rocked by accusations that Schwartz moved investor funds into his personal account. The East Harlem office project has 130,000 square feet built out for life-science tenants but was still vacant at the beginning of the summer.

REEC took over the leasehold in 2015 in a deal valued at $5M. In 2018, Terra Capital Partners injected $20M in preferred equity on a portfolio including the West 125th Street property and 286 Lenox Avenue. The next year it issued a $4.7M senior loan. Terra was acquired in 2021 by Mavik Capital Management, and the debt ended up with East West Bank, which foreclosed on the property in 2022, citing a $14.6M balance. Lakewood, New Jersey, investor Mark Tress bought the leasehold for $3.6M.
REEC teamed up with Magnum Real Estate Group in 2015 to buy a $75 million assemblage for a luxury condo development. The project was completed in 2017.
REEC acquired the ground lease in 2017 for $15.6 million but appears to have exited the condop project before it was complete.
REEC secured financing and almost closed a deal to buy the leasehold for two floors in 2016, with the option to purchase the entire property, but the owner backed out.

REEC took over the leasehold for the 15,000-sf assemblage in a 2020 deal valued at $50M. In 2022, the firm filed plans for a 73,000-sf, mixed-use commercial building and landed a $60.5M loan from Raven Capital Management, but progress stalled.

Brandon Miller bought the Water Mill property in 2011 for $3.2 million and built a mansion for his family in 2013. He took out several mortgages on the home, which was the scene of his suicide. His widow, Candice Miller, has listed the estate for $15.5M. She was sued in July for the unpaid $829,000 balance on one of the mortgages.
properties.full_address:
25 Cobb Isle Road Water Mill
 NY

properties.Description: REEC signed a 150-year ground lease in 2010 and built a three-unit co-op with a sellout price of $23 million. Miller grabbed the first sale, paying $3.9M in 2013 for the 4,000-square-foot Tribeca penthouse. He sold it for $9M in 2021. Donald Jaffe, a lender to Miller on that project and the Hamptons home, claims Miller’s widow owes him the balance on the loan: $3.6 million.

The Millers moved to a five-bedroom, $47,000-a-month rental after selling their Tribeca penthouse for $9M in 2021. Candice Miller vacated the apartment in August and is being sued for $195,000 in unpaid rent.

Candice Miller moved to this $10M condo owned by Alexander von Fürstenberg after her husband’s death. She is friends with von Fürstenberg’s wife, Alison von Fürstenberg, also known as the model Ali Kay.
properties.full_address: 50 South Pointe Drive Miami Beach FL
